contentrichtext.text: {{Location map|Antarctica| lat_deg=72|lat_min=40|lat_dir=S|lon_deg=168|lon_min=00|lon_dir=E| float=right|mark=Fire.svg|marksize=12|AlternativeMap=Antarctica relief location map.jpg| label=Victory Mountains|position=top|caption=Victory Mountains in Antarctica }} The '''Victory Mountains''' ({{coord|72|40|S|168|00|E|type:mountain|display=inline}}) is a major group of [[mountain]]s in [[Victoria Land]], [[Antarctica]], about {{convert|160|km|mi|0}} long and {{convert|80|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} wide, which is bounded primarily by [[Mariner Glacier|Mariner]] and [[Tucker Glacier|Tucker]] glaciers and the [[Ross Sea]]. The division between these mountains and the [[Concord Mountains]] (to the NW) is less precise but apparently lies in the vicinity of [[Thomson Peak]].<ref name=gnis>{{cite gnis|type=antarid|id=16041|name=Victory Mountains|accessdate=2004-11-13}}</ref> A Ross Sea aspect of the mountains was first obtained by early British expeditions of [[James Clark Ross|Ross]], [[Carstens Borchgrevink|Borchgrevink]], [[Robert Falcon Scott|Scott]] and [[Ernest Shackleton|Shackleton]]. The mapping of the interior mountains was largely done from air photos taken by the U.S. Navy and surveys undertaken by [[New Zealand]] and [[United States|American]] parties in the 1950s and 1960s. So named by the NZGSAE 1957-58, because of the proximity of this group to the [[Admiralty Mountains]], and with the intention that many of the topographic features would be named for celebrated victories, especially naval victories.<ref name=gnis/> ==See also== *[[Cartographers Range]] ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Mountain ranges of Victoria Land]] [[Category:Borchgrevink Coast]]
